To connect to the Nintendo Switch over Bluetooth, you will need to perform the following steps:

1. Make sure your Nintendo Switch is in pairing mode: On the Nintendo Switch, go to System Settings > Controllers and Sensors > Bluetooth Devices. Select "Pair New Device" to enter pairing mode.
2. Find the Switch's Bluetooth MAC address: In the "Bluetooth Devices" menu, the Switch's MAC address should be displayed under the "Pair New Device" option.
3. Put your computer into pairing mode: The specific steps to do this will vary depending on your operating system. On Windows, you can go to Settings > Devices > Bluetooth & other devices, click on "Bluetooth" and toggle it on. On macOS, you can go to System Preferences > Bluetooth, click on the "Turn Bluetooth On" button, and then select "Bluetooth Preferences...". On Linux, the process will depend on your distribution and the tools you have installed.
4. Pair your computer with the Nintendo Switch: On your computer, look for the Switch in the list of available Bluetooth devices and select it. You may need to enter a passcode to complete the pairing process. The passcode is typically 0000 or 1234.
5. Connect to the Switch using a TcpStream: Once the pairing is complete, you can connect to the Switch using the `TcpStream` type in Rust, specifying the Switch's MAC address and a known port number. For example:
```rust
let mut stream = TcpStream::connect(format!("{}:{}", MAC_ADDRESS, PORT))?;
```
6. Send control data over the TcpStream: Once you have a connected TcpStream, you can send control data to the Switch. The format of the control data will depend on the protocol used by the Switch, which may require you to send specific packets of binary data. The example Rust program I provided earlier includes some code to generate the Joy-Con control data, but you will need to customize this to match the specific requirements of the Switch's protocol.
